post: From t-shirts to tumblers, show your support for BRI by checking out our store. You can find classroom resources, apparel and accessories, and even our popular collectible stickers! Browse our store here  https://lnkd.in/euFBBmF8  #BillofRightsInstitute  #BRI  #shop

A former Bill of Rights Institutes National Teacher Council member was recently recognized by a national organization for her work with students. Jessica Culver, who teaches history at Ozark High School in Ozark, Ark., was named that states History Teacher of the Year by the Gilder Lehman Institute of American History. According to its website, teachers in each state are nominated by students, parents, other teachers, and community members. A committee of history teachers, professors, and other education professionals reviews the nominees from each state and selects the winners. Culver said she was incredibly honored  to receive the award and added she is in the company of some amazing educators from all across our country's states and territories, and it is truly meaningful to be recognized alongside so many wonderful educators.  Read more here  https://lnkd.in/ekB4YxFy

How can the Constitution help unify Americans? In this episode of Scholar Talks, Yuval Levin, Director of Social, Cultural, and Constitutional Studies at the American Enterprise Institute, joins BRI Senior Fellow Tony Williams to discuss his new book, American Covenant: How the Constitution Unified Our NationAnd Could Again. This episode explores how the Constitution can help unify Americans, the roles of federalism and localism, the importance of Congress, the contributions of the president and Supreme Court, and how stronger political parties and elections can promote unity. Watch here  https://lnkd.in/emKvntpb  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #ScholarTalks

Thank you so much to the Bill of Rights Institute for this incredible opportunity to share my work with The World in Us! The MyImpact Challenge has been an invaluable supporter for the continued development of my civic leadership journey at The World in Us and beyond. By providing $10,000 in funding, a powerful network of youth changemakers, and a framework for connecting individual service with the founding principles of our nation, the Bill of Rights Institute has deepened both the personal and community-wide impact of my work.
followers: Harvard '27 | Founder of The World in Us | Coke Scholar ‘23 | U.S. Presidential Scholar '23 | U.S. Senate Youth '22

post: We had the opportunity to catch up with Caroline Gao, the Grand Prize winner of BRI's 2023 MyImpact Challenge civic engagement contest. Listen to Caroline describe her nonprofit, The World in Us, a youth-to-youth cultural education organization, and the ways in which MyImpact Challenge helped her to connect concepts like citizenship skills and civic virtues to her work. These are foundational skills and ways of thinking that I dont think I would have internalized nearly as much as I have now if not for the MyImpact Challenge,  Gao said.  https://lnkd.in/ebyqpN3X. To support the MyImpact Challenge civic engagement contest, visit  https://lnkd.in/es_s-XFs  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #MyImpactChallenge

The Bill of Rights Institute will soon name its National Civics Teacher of the Year for the 2024-2025 school year. SmartPass, a leading provider of digital hall pass technology used by thousands of schools nationwide to increase student accountability and foster better outcomes, is joining BRIs efforts as a sponsor for this years contest. At SmartPass, our mission has always been to improve the lives of teachers and the classroom experience for our nations students,  said Peter Luba, Co-Founder and CEO of SmartPass. We are excited to partner with the Bill of Rights Institute to celebrate Americas outstanding civics teachers and the life-changing work they do in the classroom every day.  Read more at  https://lnkd.in/etbZPcrv

At the Bill of Rights Institute, we are proud to highlight our high-quality content  including stories of great courage throughout American history. In this episode of the nationally syndicated Our American Stories, Kaela Ridera former civics and history teacher from Jacksonville, Florida, who now serves as Education Programs Coordinator at the Bill of Rights Institute, tells the story of the founder of the American Red CrossClara Barton. To listen to the episode, visit  https://lnkd.in/ej_ytDm3  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #podcast

The Bill of Rights Institute was founded on the simple, powerful belief that all students should have access to a high-quality education in civics and history. 2024 marks the 25th anniversary of the founding of the Bill of Rights Institute. Read the article to see how BRI is celebrating a quarter-century of supporting educators and students in every corner of America.  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #anniversary  #civicseducation

August is Make a Will Month! The James Madison Legacy Society, BRI's planned giving opportunity, is a meaningful way to leave a legacy that will support our young people  and shape the future of civic education  for generations to come. BRI's Director of Strategic Partnerships Jennifer Seal explains more about the James Madison Legacy Society and her personal commitment to the effort. To learn more, please watch the video below or visit  https://lnkd.in/e9qDssKY. For more information, visit supportbri.org.  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #plannedgiving

For the past 25 years, the Bill of Rights Institute has worked to create meaningful partnerships and outreach opportunities to advance civic and history education. Part of that work has included working with legal organizations whose members share a deep commitment to civics and constitutional principles. BRI was proud to support the ABOTA Foundation's recent 2024 Civics Summit. The American Board of Trial Advocates (ABOTA) is a national organization of trial lawyers dedicated to equal justice in a vibrant and civil democracy. To learn more about our partnerships with legal organizations, visit  https://lnkd.in/eYuZPdQK.  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #civiceducation

At BRI, we are proud to partner with organizations like Huddle Up. Huddle Up is a leading advocate for children's growth, development, and mental health. As a sponsor of MyImpact Challenge, Huddle Up aligns with BRI's commitment to supporting communities and fostering the wellbeing of kids and teens. This year's MyImpact Challenge received over 20 mental health projects. Here are a few: Anjani Sharma, from Westshore High School in Rockledge, Florida, founded the global non-profit Minds Without B0rders  to raise awareness and promote mental health literacy and causes. Focused on storytelling, Minds Without B0rders has engaged 2,000 youth and generated 9,000 stories shared, 700 resources translated, and 5k social media followers. Anya Kawlekar, from Robbinsville High School in New Jersey, founded Mental Health Awareness in Young Athletes (MHAYA) to raise awareness of mental health issues in youth sports. And Jack Finder from San Juan Hills High School in California, authored and distributed the childrens book Mommy and Daddy Still Love Me  for children of parents going through divorce. To read more about MyImpact Challenge, visit  https://lnkd.in/gagj58zD And to learn more about our exciting partnership with Huddle Up, visit  https://lnkd.in/eata2HEf  #billofrightsinstitute  #BRI  #mentalhealthawareness
